awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Towards Automating Data Analysis: Interpretable, Interactive, and Scalable Learning via Discrete Probability
awd_abstract_narration:
As machine learning (ML) permeates all areas of science and technology, demands in diverse data domains, inference questions, resource limitations and reliability fuel several new conceptual and algorithmic challenges. Examples of current shortcomings that limit the full use of machine learning include suboptimal use of data and algorithms; painstaking hand-tuning and model search; validation of results and  difficulties in generalization; limited interactivity with humans; encoding of domain knowledge; and lack of interpretability, among others. Progress on these questions has the potential to impact the successful adoption and use of machine learning in a broad range of fields. With the above motivation, the goal of this project is to create a novel suite of models and algorithms for analyzing complex datasets, with a particular focus on the following three factors crucial for next-generation machine learning: (1) interpretability; (2) interactivity; and (3) automated learning. The overarching technical concept underlying this proposal is the concept of negative dependence in discrete probability. This project lays theoretical foundations for a new set of tools grounded in this concept. Besides practical impacts, the methods to be studied in the project motivate new theoretical questions, and will help increase interest in the underlying mathematics.

The practical impact of the proposed work has the potential to benefit society on multiple fronts. Via collaborations, the PIs will evaluate the developed methods in healthcare (seeking to ultimately impact patient care and well-being), systems biology (to help with research on cancer and diabetes, among others), and materials science (to help discover safer, functional materials more efficiently). The project will also directly have educational impact: training of graduate students, providing material for data science courses at all levels, and outreach to the community via general talks as well as focused lectures at conferences and workshops, including workshops and events targeted at women in Data Science. 

Technically, the PIs will develop: (1) New tools, models, and algorithms for interactive data analysis, especially for experimental design, information collection, interpretable machine learning, hypothesis testing, performance validation, and architecture learning; (2) Theoretical analysis, such as convergence and complexity (statistical and computational); and (3) Open-source implementations of all key algorithms and frameworks.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the project was to create a novel suite of models and algorithms for the analysis of complex datasets through the lens of discrete probability theory, especially for advancing scalable, interpretable, and interactive learning.

During the course of the project, multiple new findings were made in line with the main goal. In particular, the work developed algorithms and theory for:

  • Multi-agent reinforcement learning, Markov Games (with two or more players), Adversarial and non-stationary Markov Decision Processes, and more. This work is motivated by desire to model and understand interactive learning
  • Understanding the generalization behavior of classifiers, especially those based on deep neural networks. Improving the understanding of generalization is a central topic in modern machine learning.
  • Several foundational works on contrastive learning were published (this is an important method for learning neural embeddings of data, a crucial component of allowing deep learning to work in unsupervised settings; examples include, the work on "hard negatives" and on avoiding "shortcuts in learning"
  • Discrete probability, especially foundational theory of making learning with determinantal point processes more practical in a variety of machine learning settings, including a theory of sampling, as well as a variety fo applications. 

Some topics of the project were also covered in a new IDSS course on data science (now a capstone), as well as within MIT's (Course 6) graduate level course on introduction to machine learning.  More than 20 papers at leading conferences were published as a part of the project, and several postdocs, PhD students, and students at other levels also participated. Indeed, the central topics of project were the main topics in two PhD theses supported by the project. Finally, a broadly accessible tutorial on the topic of the project was held by its PIs at the NeurIPS 2018 conference.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/21/2023
Modified by: Suvrit Sra
